text: - All right, guys.

This is the guy we're looking
to talk to for a long time.
This is Zoltan Istvan,
and he's a futurist, he's a journalist,

but why he's here is because
he's a transhumanist.

Now, what is that, we
can get to in a second
but because it's a drinking show,
I gotta tell you what we're drinking.
These are Rob Roy's.
Scotch, sweet vermouth, Angostura bitters,

just a little stir, and
then we drop in a cherry.
Good to go.

Okay, so we can just do
a little cheers! (laughs)
All right, beautiful.
He already started drinking, so.
- Had a few drinks. (laughs)
- So I have to catch up.

Okay, off the bat, right
away, what is a transhumanist?
'Cause when you hear that, the word trans,

automatically, people
go, oh, these are people

who are transgendered
or something like that.
Explain what this is.
- So transhumanism is a social movement

now of many millions of
people around the world
that wanna use science and technology
to radically modify the human body
and also to modify the human experience.
And it can be anything
from exoskeleton suits to brain implants,
to even something like driverless cars,
but it's really usually radical technology

that wants to change what it
means to be a human being.
- I get that.
Who came up with that name?

Because that's such a
confusing name in today's world

because when you think trans,
you automatically go into,
oh, this is something with sexuality.

- It came out basically in
the in the 1930s, 1950s.
A couple different people started using it

but really it was a
movement of philosophers
in the 1990s from California.
Of course, always California, that--
- We lead the world, okay?

- We started realizing technology
was speeding up so fast
that at some point in the future,

we were really gonna be
able to cut off an arm,

put on a robotic arm
that was a lot better.
And so they formed this movement,
really called extropianism at first

but then it changed to
transhumanism as a better word.

And that word is now, over
the last five, six years
just really caught on.

It's become the de-facto term
of anything futurist related

that modifies the human being
to be something superhuman.
- I know 100% this is possible
because I know a kid born today,
provided we don't get

in any seriously nuclear
wars or something,
probably is gonna live forever,

or literally a few hundred
years very, very easily

as you have artificial
intelligence advanced
and we learn and understand
the human genome a whole lot more.
But my thing is with with transhumanists,
one of the theories that you guys push
is like this idea of immortality,
and that freaks a lot of people out

because everybody was
raised in the church,
a lot of Americans were, at least,
and they're like, wait a minute now,

you guys are trying to change
us and God made us perfect.
How do you respond to that?
- The central conflict of transhumanism
is that we live in a world

where about 80% of the
population is religious,
believes in an afterlife,

and transhumanists major
and probably primary goal
is to try to live indefinitely
through science and technology,
essentially to overcome death.
And you're right.
Anybody born under 15 or under 20

almost is guaranteed to
live as long as they want,

as long as there's no
asteroid or terrible plague
or something, a nuclear war, perhaps,
but I think people our age,
I think we're ahead of that cutting board.
The last generation, will we make it?
Will we not?
But yeah, there's no question

that there is now billions
and billions of dollars,
a lot of it, again, from California,

flowing into what we call
the life extension industry
and it's either through genetic editing
or uploading your consciousness
or through stem-cell technologies,
or different types of ways

that you can make your
body live a lot longer,
and hopefully all the way, indefinitely.
- So we've already seen instances,

I know they have been able to
do age reversal in lab rats.
So where are we now on that front?
- They have done that,

and really the big challenge
with any kinda drugs
and any research in America

is actually getting permission
to do it in bigger animals
and then in human trials.
Any drug, and this is one of the problems

with the system in America is
anything takes about 10 years
to get through the pipeline
so while we've already done the rat test
four or five six years ago,
it's gonna take a lot longer

before we can actually
start doing human trust.

Now, there are a couple human
trials underway right now

but it's not the big,
giant ones that we want

where billions of dollars
are pouring into it.
We probably already have the technology
to at least figure out
if some of these ways will stop aging,
and we think they will
because they've done it in other mammals,

but yeah, the government's
standing in the way.
And of course, not to bash religion,
but our president, our vice president,
nine Supreme Court justices,
basically every member of Congress
at least on paper claims to be religious
and believe in an afterlife
so they don't really have this incentive
to put money into the life extension field
so people can live longer

because their belief systems
don't really want that.
They're what we call deathtists.

They believe--
- That we have to die.

- That we have to die in
order to meet our maker.
And I understand that philosophy

but the reality is,
transhumanists are mostly secular
and they wanna put our money here

while we're still alive
to the ones we love
and keep them alive as long as possible.
- But what if I can make this argument
that everyone is a transhumanist,
it depends on the marketing pitch
because nobody really wants to die.
You have people go around, I wanna die,

and we all assume that we
can grow old very peacefully

and die in our sleep which
is never the way it happens.

But my thing is what if
you market it differently

and go, okay, well, here's
what we could do, guys.
You could take this medication
and this would then get rid
of diabetes, hypertension, and this,

and this will help you
to live a little longer,
but never really come out and be,
hey, we're selling immortality.
- So no, no.
And in fact, I'm known

as one of the big provocative
tools against the movement.
I get myself in trouble a lot

because I do things like
drive crazy coffin buses
across the country.
In somewhat of a bombastic fashion,

I create a conflict in
order that media coverage
will then appear for transhumanism
because it's such a small-fringe movement.
I mean, now it's growing,
but five years ago was a fringe movement,
it needed media coverage.
So clashes were great.
But now that I've actually started
speaking at the World Economic Forum,
the World Bank, places like that,
I've actually toned down a lot
and I'm becoming much more diplomatic

because I realize that
if we can't sell this

to a Christian nation,
we can't sell it at all

so we better say, hey, this
is not about living forever
or challenging religion,

this is just about you
being able to spend 100,
maybe 200 years with your grandchildren.
Don't you want that?

And then everyone says,
that sounds pretty nice.
And so then it's a different thing.
But I've gotten better at being moderate.
- Yeah, 'cause I was saying,

'cause if you go behind
this immortality road,
you can have some Christian activists,

might not even be Christian,
'cause it could be any religion
'cause most religions sell some afterlife,

who goes, oh my god, this
guy's the antichrist,
I need to take these transhumanists out.

- No, they've said that
about me lots of times.
I get hate email, I get death threats,
but I have toned it down

because I think the more
popular the movement has gone

and the more popular my own
writings also have gone,

now in The New York Times
and things like that,
I have to actually be a lot more balanced.

And frankly, a lot of
my supporters like that.
I think a lot of them were a bit upset

that sometimes I provoked
too much in my early days.
When you start a new movement,

when the environmental
movement started out

and Greenpeace was the
very first organization,
they did some crazy things
and they did some very wild things

but that's what launched
the environmental movement

is at the backbone of these
activists, and then later,

environmentalism became a
very professional industry.

I think transhumanism is going
through that similar phase.
- Okay.
So let me ask you about some of the things
that you see in transhumanism now.
So Elon Musk has Neuralink, his company,
and his goal is that you have
artificial intelligence evolving
and if we evolve independently of that,

at some point, artificial
intelligence could take over

and it could be a great
world where we live forever
and we have this great robot overlord
or it could be Skynet coming to kill us.

And so he wants to input, implant
these chips in our brains.
Now, my question about that is
whenever tech guys sell you something,
it's always a catch.

I ain't knocking Elon
Musk, I'm just saying

they always collecting
information on the backend,
behind the scenes, it's this, it's that,
so can we trust someone like him
who's smarter than most people out there?
'Cause if he gives me a chip,
I can't figure out how this chip works
so I just have to trust him.
How do I know that these guy
is actually working for my wellbeing?
'Cause you can put something in my mind
where you control me.
- I'm not that worried.
When you look at historically speaking,
the world has become a lot more improved
through science and technology.
We can rest on that huge fact.

I think when it comes to
somebody, specifically Elon Musk,
okay, yes, we have to take some care.

We don't wanna just put
stuff into our brains.
But honestly, you have to also take,
just take a larger historical perspective.
AI could be very dangerous.

If we don't merge with
AI and yet we create it,
that would definitely be the worst thing.

What we need to do is I think
put implants into our brains
and as we launch that AI, be one with it,

connect with it, utilize
it, almost merge with it.
And that way, we can be certain

that the robots won't
become the Terminator

because we've become the
Terminator in itself.
I think from a game theory perspective,
that's the only way to move forward.
For that reason alone,
I'm trustworthy of all tech companies
because I think they also realize
that this is game over for all of us
if we do this the wrong way,

but I also think that we also
have to be very cautious.
We can't just stick stuff in our head
and just say okay, it's all good.

It's not like a phone where
we can take out of our pocket
and throw out the window.
The chips stuck.
I have a implant and--
- Yes, yes, you do!

- I have a tiny implant,
it opens my front door,
can start a car, sends out a text message,
does all sorts of funny little things.
It's more a party trick gimmick.

It doesn't really do
anything too sophisticated.
It does replace keys.

But God, I've been
really happy to have it.
- Do you use it often?

- Well, on my front
door, I can only use it.
That's all that's set up.
So I only have a reader.
- Does your wife have a reader too?
- No, my wife has a key code

that she can press in.
(host laughs)
Because we wanted to get the implants
for my children as well but actually,
there are rules against getting implants
for children at that age.

There's all sorts of different
types of technicalities.

Well, I can do it and
we're not even so sure
if it's so legal for me
because every state has a different rule
against what you can put in your body
when it's not FDA-approved.
But anyways, so my kids and my wife
just punch in code but I scan.
- (laughs) That is awesome!
Does your wife buy in to all of this,
the transhumanist movement?
- My wife's a physician.
She's an ob/gyn.
- She's a doctor!
His wife is a doctor!
- She has also two research degrees.
She does not buy into it.
She likes it.

She thinks it's awesome what's
happening with the world,
the technological innovations and whatnot.
Does she wanna live forever?
I'm not sure.
I think she would say I don't know yet.
Does she support all that I do?

She supports me, but I think
she doesn't necessarily agree
with a lot of it yet.
- So do her friends call and be like,
hey, is your weird husband there?
Oh, no, he's not?
Okay, I'm coming over.

(host laughs)
- Well, no, no, of course!

The big argument we always have
going back to Elon Musk is,
can we, in 10 or 15 years' time,

when we have this chip in
our head, download education?
And if we can, should I stop saving
for my daughter's college funds?
And I say, yes, let's stop saving.
It's so much easier.
Spend the money on ourselves.
And my wife says, "Hell no, hell no.
"We're not gonna stop.

"We're not gonna trust your
chip downloading education idea,

"they're gonna go to normal
schools like we all went."

and I'm like, so when it
comes to things like that,
that's what my wife puts her foot down
and says we're not gonna cross that line.

But there's a good chance
that probably within 15 years,

we will have implants in our
head, we could if we wanted,

that could download
education, algebra, calculus.
- You would, 'cause that's one of the,

again, that's one of the things
that Elon Musk is pitching

that hey, okay, so you
can't fly a helicopter,
but if you have this implant,

then you go into that file and
you download all those notes

and you immediately know
how to handle a helicopter.

- Yeah, it's just like the
matrix and it's so close!
They're now racing drones.

I just did an article
for The New York Times
where I discussed this.

In Florida where they race
drones around the track
just wearing headsets,

it's the same thing as an
implant, except it's a headset,

it reads your brainwaves,
they don't touch anything,
the drones liftoff and fly around a track
and they're racing them.

That's how far this telepathy
brainwave technology
has already come.
So where will it be in 10 years?

We could be playing the
piano, Mozart's 5th Symphony.

Again, my eight-year-old
daughter takes piano lessons.
We pay a lot of money for it.
And I'm like, why, when she's 21,

she can just download
Mozart's 5th Symphony
and be perfect at it!
- No, 'cause I agree.

You could see, if you open
your mind and look around,

'cause I'm sure there are
people watching us right now

who are going, nah, these
guys' out of their mind,
but there is no more science fiction.

A line no longer exists
'cause every day, you wake up,
and if you google AI,
you will see some new discovery

or some new threshold
that they've crossed.
Sometimes, there is hype
but there are real, real advances, man.

So let me ask you this
question about your kids.

You would edit your
kids' DNA if it was legal
and you could make them,
let's say, better at certain things?
- Well, totally.
In my family runs heart disease.
I would have absolutely eliminated that.

But would I have made them
taller, stronger, smarter?

The answer is what
parent wouldn't do that?
We all would, if we could press a button
and say my child's gonna be as strong

and healthy and as
intelligent as possible,
we'd all press the button.
And this is where it gets this crazy world
with China and America right now too.

China's now leading the rush
on genetic editing development.
They've done some of the very first
embryo altercations essentially,

and have children that
are genetically modified,
and they might be the very first country
that puts forth a generation of children

that have higher IQs through
genetic editing modification
and what will that mean

from a national security
issue for America?

Imagine if you're just, you
knew somebody on the street,
just had better intelligence than you
because somebody pre-programmed it
before that person was even born?

It's all of a sudden from
a job market workplace,
it becomes different.
This is what's happening.

- No, I mean, I don't
think parents have a choice

because if you see people begin
upgrading which will happen.

A matter of fact, I believe
it already has happened
because if you are a topnotch geneticist
and you know what you're doing,
why would you not modify your DNA?

Why would you wait on the FDA
to say hey, you have approval.
That could take years, like you just said!
So if I'm in my lab,

so I know that you probably
have modified humans out there
but if we start doing that and your kid,
and you said, no, I don't want to,
your kid will be light years behind

'cause that is like you would
not be sufficient to keep up!
- And that's the promise

because once you get
behind in this society,

it's really hard to catch up.
- To catch up.

- That's why the rich are getting
richer, the poor and poor.

If the society is getting
more fragmented as we go in,
and it's not just with wealth,

it's with intellectual power
and all these other things.

And if that continues, we'll
never catch up to the trends.
It'll be game over in a way from,
I think, a cultural and a financial,
and a lot of different points of view.

I do some consulting
with the U.S. Military
on all these other things.
I keep telling them

even though we have a
Conservative government
that's really afraid of these things,
wants to put moratoriums on these things,

we have to push forward
as quickly as possible

with these technologies because
if we don't win the race,
they're going to.

- Where is the U.S. Military
on this in your opinion?

- Well, the U.S. Military
is essentially controlled,
I think, by Judo-Christian culture
which says we're really not wanting
to modify the human body,
let's just make a lot of drones
and bombs and things like that.

But the reality is as we
move forward culturally
and we move forward with what's better
for maybe sports and things like that
and just also just procreation,
obviously, genetically editing ourselves

so we don't have heart
disease or we don't get cancer

or we never get Alzheimer's,
or we all have IQs of 180,
that's the most beneficial thing.

And so countries that
don't have the kind of,

I suppose conservative
hangups that we have
are gonna move forward on this much faster
than America will.
- One of the things you wrote about
I think was a New York Times article

where you talked about
having a transhuman Olympics,
wherein people who have been modified,

allowing them to compete
against other modified people.
- So, yeah.
Right now in Switzerland,

we have what we call the
Cybathlon which is this--
- What's it called, Cyberthon?
- No, Cyblathon.
- Cyblathon, okay.
- It's this weird word
but basically it's cyborg and thon,

but it is what they also
call a Cyborg Olympics.

And essentially, it's most
people are missing limbs

so they're either
paraplegic, quadriplegic,
or missing limbs entirely

and they're basically what
they call pilots or avatars,

they put on different types
of brain-reading headsets.
So you have a guy with no legs
who is doing a bicycle race

against somebody else with
no legs around the track.

They're thinking the thoughts
that make their muscles move
and because they have electrodes
to their brain and to their legs.
It's fascinating.

Actually, the most
interesting thing about that
is when they do this bicycle race,

they have to make sure they
don't overthink their legs
because they can wear out their muscles

without even knowing they're
wearing up their muscles
because they can't feel it.
- Oh, yeah!
- So there's all these different types

of technological things that
are built into this software
to make sure that they don't,
'cause otherwise, it'd be like,
we'll go 5,000 miles per hour

except their legs wouldn't
be able to respond.
- Oh, okay.
- That's really where this cyborg Olympics
becomes really fascinating.

But that's just where we
are here in 2016 and 2020.
Where we're really going is

when you can take a
football with a bionic arm

and probably be here in
maybe five to 10 years,

and throw it half a mile
with total precision.
That also is gonna be here.
So when we look out 10, 15 years,

what is the sporting
environment gonna be like?
Well, it could get very, very radical.

There's these people that
are building bionic boots
that it can allow them to run already 25,

basically as fast as you say
Bolt, the champion runner.
- Usain Bolt, yeah.
- Yeah, they think they're gonna be able
to get them to run so fast

that they might even
be able to run on water
using exoskeleton technology.

So you would run out to
the ocean a half mile
and you would do your jog out there.

- 'Cause in your article,
you said in order to do that,
everybody go wow!

You would need to, you said,
go run at 67 miles an hour.

- Yeah, an Italian bunch
of scientists did a report

and they said in order for a
human being to run on water,

they have to be able to
keep up 67 miles per hour.
But exoskeleton technology will probably,
at some point in the next 10 or 20 years
allow us to do that.
They'll be like (imitates vibration).

And if you get these kinda
paddles on the back of your legs,

you'll just be like, okay,
now I'm running on water.
That's the future of sports,

that marathons may take
place across the ocean.

- So one of the things
I wanna ask you about
is this concept of the singularity.
Explain what that is.

- So the singularity is this
kind of quasi science idea
but basically, it says that at some point,
technology becomes so sophisticated,
like artificial intelligence,
that our own human brain

can no longer even
understand how it works.
AI or artificial intelligence

then starts growing upon
itself and very quickly,
the microprocessor can exponentially grow.
Even if it's not following Moore's Law,

it's still every 18 to 24
months, doubling in capacity.

The singularity is where all
the technological innovation

that happens in a minute is
more technological innovation
than all of history combined.
Because it's so fast!

And the microprocessor
goes from a gazillion bits

to a trillion gazillion
bits in literally seconds.
That's what transhumanists see
as the final destination of our species
is we don't look at an afterlife
where we sit there with harps
and feeding ourselves or whatever.
We look at this technological singularity
where that's where we maybe end up.

We end up embedded in
artificial intelligence,
our intelligence spanning the cosmos,

maybe actually becoming one
with subatomic particles,
or everything's just conscious of itself.
It's almost a Gaia thing
except it's very scientifically based.

- And most scientists feel
that this would happen when,
in your opinion?

- So a lot of people say
it's gonna happen by 2050.
Frankly, it could happen earlier

and it could also happen in
a hundred years from now.
I think it's guaranteed to happen but--

- I mean, most of them
agree that it will happen,
it's just a matter of when.

'Cause what it really is is
when machines become sentient,
when they pretty much become human,
they could understand, they could talk.
- There's just a chance

that they become so
sophisticated very quickly

and they say let's make ourselves
very sophisticated more,
and then all of a sudden,

they go from two to four
to eight to 60 and 32
and in a matter of hours,
and they're just like the sci-fi movies,

this is not necessarily
only science fiction,

this is really how computer
technology can operate.
Once it figures out how to do something,

its speed just is astounding
from a human brain perspective.
You have to understand.
Our human brains are three pounds of meat

but an AI that learns
how to use the internet
that spans across every single server
in every single major city

and uses all that computational
power is gonna have,
I'm not sure exactly how many times

but billions and billions
of times more capacity
than we would essentially have.

That's why it's very important
that we don't let AI run off
because it leaves us behind so quickly.
- Yeah.
For those of you that are confused,

'cause there's three divisions
of artificial intelligence.
Well, you have the narrow AI
which is what Siri is on your phone.
Siri can do very specific things,
or a driverless car could just drive

but then you get to general
artificial intelligence
where a machine now is able to do
a lot of these different things,
and it's super intelligence
as that machine begins to build on itself
and begin to understand a lot more
and then leaves us behind.
I hope I explained that correctly.
- Yeah, yeah, no, and that's right.
- Yeah, that's interesting.

Okay, so you were in real
estate in the beginning, right?

- Well, the beginning
was National Geographic.
- Okay.

- So I began my career
at National Geographic
right out of college and did five years,

That's why I was drawn to transhumanism
is I saw quite a bit of death

When my father got sick,

which luckily did very well

and allowed me then to
pursue my other passions.
And because I'd been in these war zones,
my passion was overcoming death.

And so I dedicated myself to
the transhumanist movement
by writing books and writing articles.

A book of mine called "The
Transhumanist Wager" went off
and did very well.

- That's why check out his
book, "The Transhumanist Wager".
- "The Transhumanist Wager".
In fact, I just got a phone call

Eventually, we've had discussion for it.

Eventually, the book will
be made into a movie.
- Oh, really?
- So I'm hopeful of that too.

Ever since then, I've
been writing articles,

but what mainly happened is
what a lot of people know me for
is that in late 2014,
I realized that transhumanism
did not have a political component
and I formed the transhumanist party
and then was its nominee
for the presidential election in 2016.

And lo and behold, despite
being an unknown person,
the science candidacy really took off
and we ended up doing 100 million views,
and we ended up being focused,
covered by major media all the time.
We had a giant 40-foot coffin bus
which we drove across the country.
- He has ran for president, okay?

So there's a second presidential
candidate on the show.
- We trafficked very good.
And they said at some point,
we're trafficking either fifth or sixth
of all the candidates who finished.

So there's Trump, Hillary,
Jill Stein, and Gary Johnson,

and then either myself was
probably next or one other
and in terms of traffic.
Now, it's hard because we were not always
getting that many votes

because we weren't on
all those state ballots.
In fact, it was very hard to get any.
However, we actually trafficked a lot
meaning for what we are trying to do,
we were not trying to win the presidency,
we were just trying to say hey,
if you vote for me in office,
I will make it sure that you will live
as long as you wanna live.
I will overcome death as your presidency.
And that was really our main ticket
is to spread transhumanism in the media

and just talk about
science in a different way.

Nobody had ever spoken about
science on the campaign trail
up until that point and in a real way,
and that's what we did.
That's the history!
- That's interesting.
So one of the things is I know
a lot of the Silicon Valley guys now

are trying everything in
their power to avoid death

'cause they know that we
will get to this point
where we'll be able to solve that mystery.

So what are you doing to
try to prolong your life?
- What's interesting about myself
is that I'm quite a bit younger
than a lot of the other people
that you might see in public roles.
Age makes a huge difference.

One of the reasons I'm
so into transhumanism

and robotic limbs and brain
implants, things like that,
is because I'm still quite healthy
but a lot of 60 and 70-year-old academics
are all interested in life extension
because they're like, I'm gonna die soon,
so I'm freaking out.
